div.p: A FULL RELATION OR DIALOGUE Between a Loyalliſt and a converted PHANATTICK ſince the time of the late Rebellion, relating their wicked conſpiracy, and barbarous intentions, whereby their divelliſh plots is more fully diſcovered then ever it was before: Gently diſputed between them both. Together with the Phanaticks Lamentation and farewell to that Crew.
Publiſhed as a warning-piece to all Rebellious Sectaries.

div.head: A Dialogue betwen a LOYALIST and a PHANATTICK.

sp.p: STand! who approacheth there ſo néer the walls of our Government, lurking in the dark like a ravening wolf in ſhéeps cloathing?

p.hi: Behold O man and ſee! for lo it is I, even thy fellow creature, and one of the faithful,

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ſay you ſo indéed; are you one of the faithfull? in good faith by and by I ſhall try your fidelity.

p.hi: Then take me and try me, for thou ſhalt not find me to be even as other men are!

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Why truly it is very likely ſo, and I ſhall take your bare word for't, wherein I took you at firſt to be an honeſt man, now I doubt I ſhall find you to be a knave.

p.hi: Why, even as thou findeſt me, ſo mayſt thou leave me.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: No don't you believe that I will part with you ſo ſoon, untill you have declared unto me the ſecrets of your breſt.

p.hi: What knoweſt thou not O man what the word ſays, that a revealer of ſecrets is no leſs then a fool

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Gad it is to be feared that you are more knave then fool, therefore demonſtrate unto me what you are!

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: I ſhall anſwer unto thee O man, That I am one of the Tribe of Ephraim who now am come to advance the Cauſe of the righteous, and to ſeek after the reſt of my brethren.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: I, ſo it ſeems you are a brood with a pox to ye, but we ſhall be as careful to look after them as you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.p: Nay, but I tell thee O man, they are a people elected.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: I believe ſo, for Dan has a great ſuſpition of it.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Of their innocency he may, for they have done nothing but what they muſt anſwer for

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: I, anſwer for't) without diſpute, either guilty or not guilty they muſt ſay.

p.hi: Verily, verily they thought no more harm, but to ſearch out all that were not of their Sect, and ſmite them to the ground with the edg of the ſword, which as we counted was the work of the juſt

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Why then juſtly they ſhall have their reward for't Ile warrant ye, even to a tittle of what they deſerve.

p.hi: Why indeed as the labourer is worthy of his hire, even according to the Word ſo let it be.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: But were there not a great many hirelings amongſt them, think you?

p.hi: Yes, there were many that came out by hands even to advance the cauſe of th faithfull, being a people cal'd and led by the ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: I, but others do imagine they were led by the Divel elſe humane nature would have bluſh't at their boldneſs.

p.hi: No no, alas they were of undaunted ſpirits in the fancy they took to, that they feared neither God nor Divel.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Why, ſo the people report indéed they were of ſuch magnanimous ſpirits, men far more flitter for the Gallows then a Garriſon.

p.hi: Yea, in the City do I imagine ſo, but truly, truly they were ſo zealous in all their ways, that whatſoever idle fancy they took to, they would ſtand it out to the laſt.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: So it ſéems indéed, but now I doubt they'l be hang'd fort at laſt, poor harmleſs Athiſts, 'tis a thouſand pitties that ever one of them ſhould dye in their beds.

p.hi: Nay, but hearken unto the words of my mouth O man, and I ſhall ſpeak unto thee. For as I lay in my bed my thoughts troubled me, and I heard a voyce ſay unto me, ariſe and girt on thy ſword, and fight the battel of the faithfull, then I awaked out of my ſleep and did as I was commanded, for the ſpirit did move me.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: No, the Divel did move you, that evill ſpirit, on purpoſe to raiſe up the throne of Antichriſt, and ſo crown your ſelves with the horn of Rebellion.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.p:
Nay but O man our meaning was not ſo, nor our intentions, no more but to abolliſh all Laws, and ſubdue all Satutes, O what an eaſe would it have brought to the Lawyers. Secondly, to have caſt off both King and Government, then what a liberty had we given to the Nation. Thirdly, to have puld down all Churches, and
Chappels, O then what a trouble had we quitted the Clergy of. Fourthly, to have brought all things under our power, O then what a government had the people then lived under?

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Yes, and I believe you would have maſſacred in houſes too, before you would have fall'd in your wicked Enterpriſes

p.hi: O man, the Spirit did call us thereunto, and bid us fight valiantly, and ſpare not one alive contrary to our Sect, which thing muſt be done before we could accompliſh this mighty work that the ſpirit hath moved us to take in hand.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Why truly you may ſée what the Spirit hath done for you and how it hath led you, firſt to Newgate, then ſhortly to Tyburn, where he will leave you to your deſerved merits.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.p: Verily, verily I ſhall anſwer unto thee again and ſay, That our hoſt were numerous had they béen but together, and our power innumerable, but there came others more mightier then they, and ſmote them back and ſide, and ſlew them, where-now they remain for the ſins of their bretren, and cannot obtain this mighty work.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p:
Yes, I believe it is too mighty for
for you to accompliſh.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.p: Hear thou me and I will anſwer thee again, we were a people of the faithful, and did not intend to do it with the hands of men.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: What did ye intend to do it with the hands of Divels?

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.p: Not we did intend to do it by prayer, and though our hearts did pray, yet our hands ſhould fight, and though we flew as many in number as the ſand on the Sea ſhore, yet would we leave a Remnant alive to wonder at the deeds we ſhould do.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: No marvel indéed to wonder at the déeds you ſhould do, when ſo many thouſand do wonder at the déeds you have done already, but you know what the Word ſays, The trée that bringeth not forth good fruit, wall be cut down and caſt into the fire.

p.hi: Nay fellow creature I muſt tell thee.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Nay don't tearm me thy fellow creature, for I am none of thy fellows.

p.hi: Why then I ſhall thee O man the prudency of our Counſels are turned into fooliſhneſs and the hand of the City has bin upon us.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Have a care the hands of the hung doth not fall on you.

p.hi: Why, ſhall the faithful dye for the ſins of the people?

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: No, but they ſhall dye for their divelliſh Rebellion.

p.hi: Nay then I will ſit down and complain of my miſery, that my brethren doth ſuffer, and none regardeth them.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: No not many thou mayſt be ſure.

sp.speaker: Phan.

p.hi: Alas alas our brethren were ſaintly divine creatures, and as innocent as the beaſt of the field, they loved all fleſh alike.

sp.p: They hated not each others wives, but loved them as they loved their own.
They lid'd ſo charitable one with another, that rather then they would part they would go to Newgate together.
They would wrong no man ſacretly, but in the ſtreets kill them openly.
They were the judicious perſons in the world, (putting treaſon and baſeneſs aſide.
There was few men of more conſtancy then they were, but 'twas among themſelvs.
They were the learnedſt Schollers that ever was, For they would coyn ſuch new ſence for Scripture words, that never was heard nor known before.
They were likewiſe the valianteſt Souldiers that ever was, confeſſing they were alwayes led by a ſp'rit.

They were alſo accounted for the
bouldeſt men that ever I knew, for they could look through the grandeſt piece of impudence, without being a whit aſhamed: they were the greateſt lovers of Churches that ever was, for they would willingly have pul'd them down to have paved their yards with the ſtones thereof. Nay, they knew that amongſt all theſe vertues if they were taken they ſhould be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Why truly it is the general report of the City, eſpecially for theſe thrée v v v, Vice, Villany, and Vaniy, and for thrée b b b, Bloody, Baſe, and Buſie, and for thrée t t t, Troubles, Treaſon, and Treachery, whereby you may ſearch Bedlam, Bridewell and Newgate, and hardly find any to exceed them.

p.hi: Verily I anſwer and ſay unto thee that theſe are the latter days my brethren do live in.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Why truly Dun has a great ſuſpition of it, that 'tis their latter days they live in now.

p.hi: Why, ſo I mean, but will ye believe me?

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: 'Tis a queſtion whether I ſhall or no for times are dangerous.

p.hi: Why indeed it is a tottering age we live in, for the word ſays we are here to day and gon to morrow.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Your brethren at Newgate cannot ſay ſo except it be the day before their Execution.

p.hi: Why verily I anſwer thee according to the word, we live in a very uncertain time, for a man does not know the day he ſhall dye on.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Yes in good ſaith, when your brethren are going up Holbuern they have a ſhrew'd gueſs what day they are to dye on.

p.hi: Alas, they were innocent and harmleſs creatures, they never do no hurt but what they do willingly.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Why, ſo the report is, but Monday and Wedneſday they could do but little or nothing.

p.hi: Alas they could do no more then what they were able, though they endeavoured as much as any men alive.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Yes I believe they did, but they ſhould have march't in order, and have choſe ſome honeſt religious men to command ye.

p.hi: Indeed there was thee honeſt men to have come which was Hewſon, Okey and Ludlow, but had they come and been taken, you would ſurely have hang'd them.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p:
Yes truly and not only them, for they have got ſuch a uſe of hanging, that
that they do not care to hang the greateſt Traytor in England.

p.hi: I but our people did not intend to be hang'd when they came out.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Very likely ſo indéed! but how did you come to joyn with the Righteous to advance the cauſe of the faithful?

p.hi: Why truly I ſhall tell thee O man, from the uprightneſs of my heart, how according to my belief the ſpirit did move me.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Yes I warrant thée the ſpirit did move thée, more likely the Divel did move thée, therefore declare to me the very truth.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.p: Why then behold O man, on Wedneſday morning Ian. 9. as I lay in my bed I was troubled, and I heard a voice ſay, come away, for the day of the faithful appeareth: then I aroſe and took my woollen veſtment alſo with me: and the woman that was given to be with me, ſaid, O man whether departeſt thou? I ſaid to her, I go to ſeek the faithful: ſhe anſwered me again, go and proſper. No ſooner was I come out at the North door, but I eſpyed, and beheld afar off a band of men, and I drew neer unto them, and they drew near unto me, and ſaid unto me who art thou,
I anſwered and ſaid, I am one of the faithful.

p.hi: Then they anſwered and ſaid draw near, and be it unto thee even as thou haſt ſaid.

sp.p: Then we communed and walked together, and ſought counſel by prayer; and being come into Cheapſide we met with our Enemies, who aſſaulted us and ſmote us, both back and ſide, and caſt us into bonds, ſo this was the overthrow of the righteous, and if there is ought done againſt thee, 'tis I a ſervant of the Lord, teſtifie thou againſt me.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: I teſtify againſt thee, that thou and the reſt of thy brethren did ſeek to maintain Kingly Government, to keep up the Clergy, and to continue the Laws both for the preſervation of Prince and peaſant.

p.hi: I tell thee O man that thy teſtimony is not according to truth, for we never intended any of theſe things, but as we were led by the ſpirit, our intention was to pull down all Government, to ſubvert the Laws, deſtroy the Clergy, to ſet up Bell and Dragon, and live under the means and ſweat of other mens labours.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Nay but you did intend to raiſe another great Tax, and to repaire and beautifie the Church of Saint Pauls, and to rectifie the Altar.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.p:
Nay but O man I ſhall anſwer again,
and ſay thou art in an Error, for the ſpirit did move us to pull it down, and to remove the Altars from their places.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: And again you did intend to erect more new Colledges in both Vniverſities, and make the Nation mad with learning.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.p: I tell thee again O man as I am bound to anſwer to my charge that it is falſe alſo: for we were to confound learning, and deſtroy they univerſities with the three Original tongues, Latine, Greek, and Hebrew, becauſe our opinion ſhould never be confuted:

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Nay but you would have made ſuch an Order in the City, as to have Elected two Lord Mayors, four Sheriffs, and twice as many Aldermen.

sp.speaker: Phan,
sp.p: I anſwer thee again O man, 'tis very falſe, for we did never intend any ſuch thing, for our intention was to have had no Lord Mayor, Sheriff, nor Alderman, but every one to be Governor, and Teacher of his own houſe.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: And again it is plainly made apparent that you did intend for to erect more Printing houſes, becauſe all the Preſſes in town could not Print off ſo faſt as your Authours did write.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.p: Verily I ſay unto thee, That a flight of ſnow on May day is more welcomer to us then either Printing or learning, nay we did ſo much diſaffect it, that we intended to have taught each other without Bell, Book, or Candle, and ſo to have béen as innocent as the beaſt in the field, that knows neither good nor evil.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Nay, its further laid to your charge that you had ſuch inclination to Languages that you kept Tranſlators in your houſes.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.p: I ſhall anſwer unto thee O man, that we were not inclined to Languages, but was content with the ſame we was born withall, and for Tranſlators we never had any but our Shoo-repairers.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: But did ye not intend to teach when you came into Cheap-ſide to the Standard.

p.hi: No no, we did intend to meet and aſsemble our ſelves together, and put our hoſt in order for the mighty work we were cal'd to.

sp.speaker: Loy.
sp.p: Yes a mighty work you had to do before we met with you, at Woodstreet, Colledg-hill, and Cornwall.

p.hi: O man our enemies met with us too ſoon which makes me add the lamentation of a bad market, for the hands of the City have been upon us.

lg.head: His lamentation and farewell to all Sects.
lg.l: What now I ſay, that muſt I néeds,
The hands of ye City have bin on our heads
that ſpirit which within our hearts did lurk
And put us now upon this mighty work,
Hath even ſo betray'd us into thrall,
And brought our teachers into bondage all:
That very curſe which was on curſed Cain
Is now befell amongſt my brethren,
Our ſelf-opinion teachers now is clad,
with ye very plague ye Pharaohs Egiptians had
Being unbelievers through Hipocricy,
We're drowned all within the Ocean Sea,
Iuſt even ſo we made Religion new,
And juſtifi'd it like as if we knew,
the hearts of Angels in their contemplation
Although 'twas nothing but diſſimulation,
Led by a ſpirit which did us undo
And now hath ruin'd our Religion too,
Then farewell Sects, & farewell Sectaries,
Farewell to Schiſme and to Hypocriſſes,
Farewell to méeting-houſes, and adiue
To teaching-houſes farewell unto you,
Farewel to Biſhopſgate we uſe to méet,
Farewel to preaching in the open ſtréet,
For now the Bull and mouth at Alderſgate,
Within this fortnight is to be let
What, have the tenants lately Newgate took
That now the Bull & mouth they have forſook,
A place moſt fit, the time was then,
Bedlam, and Bridewel did complain of them.
